Philips doesnâ€™t need AI; it needs Focus 


In recent years, AI has become a corporate buzzword, with many companies across various industries rushing to integrate it into their products and marketing materials to signal their innovative status and even boost valuation. The wave initially began in the tech sector but soon spread to other industries, including healthcare. By 2024, over 40% of S&P 500 CEOs mentioned AI in their earnings calls.


Although some of the big tech companies have successfully demonstrated value creation using AI, for many others, the pressure to adopt AI has been mainly driven by FOMO and a desire to improve market perception, rather than a strategic necessity.  This ultimately explains why, a year later, the same executives acknowledged a significant gap between their desired and actual outcomes.


Running AI at scale requires substantial upfront investment, as well as ongoing development and operational costs, with no guaranteed short-term returns. This may not be a concern for companies with access to significant cash. However, for most other companies, especially those facing financial challenges, their resources would be better allocated somewhere else.


This is especially true for Philips. After decades of continuous restructuring, downsizing, and spin-offs, what the company needs now more than anything is focus, not distraction. Chasing AI, however appealing, could distract Philips from its core internal challenges, including operational inefficiencies and a lack of ROI on its R&D activities. To position itself better for sustainable growth in the long term, Philips should focus on two critical priorities.


Simplifying Operations

Philips' operations are very costly, which leaves almost no margin for profit. For comparison, Philips has very similar products to GEHC and nearly identical revenue. Yet Philips has 14,000 more employees. But it is not just the number of employees; Philips also has a very centralized approach to its operation, which significantly increases its managerial overhead. Philips needs to adopt a more decentralized model, internally separating business units, empowering each of its divisions to operate with greater autonomy, and shifting away from global operations. This will enable each division to focus on its customers, operations, and unique value propositions.


Focusing R&D

The same applies to R&D. Philips is one of the top R&D spenders in the industry, yet this high investment has delivered little revenue growth, signaling inefficiencies. Rather than pursuing global or fundamental research, Philips should empower each business unit to focus on product research that directly benefits its customers. Philips has built its reputation through decades of excellence in medical imaging and patient monitoring. Instead of diluting its focus with broad AI initiatives, Philips should double down on its core competencies, co-developing solutions in close partnership with clinicians and scientists.
